questions.text: A 13 year old boy presents with mushroom like swelling which is not painful over medial aspect of distal femur for past 1 year. Which of the following criteria can be used to suspect probable malignant transformation?
questions.solution:
Mushroom like swelling near knee which is not painful is likely to be osteochondroma.

Osteochondroma

  • Benign surface lesions probably arise secondary to aberrant cartilage (from the perichondrial ring) on the surface of bone. Though the tumour originates at the growth plate, it gets 'left behind' as the bone grows in length, and thus comes to lie at the metaphysis and it seems that the tumour is growing away from the joint. The stalk and part of the head of the tumour are made up of mature bone, but the tip is covered with cartilage.

Presentation

  • Painless mass discovered incidentally.
  • Occurs about the knee, proximal femur, and proximal humerus.

Imaging

  • Characteristic appearance: A surface lesion in which the cortex of the lesion and the underlying cortex are confluent with the medullary canal
  • Osteochondroma may have a narrow stalk (pedunculated) or a broad base (sessile).
  • The lesion typically occurs at the site of a tendon insertion, and the affected bone is abnormally wide.
  • Underlying cortex is covered by a thin cap of cartilage (usually only 2-3 mm thick; in a growing child, the cap thickness may be around 1-2 cm). >2cm should arise suspicion of malignant transformation.

Histology: Chondrocytes are arranged in linear clusters, in appearance resembling the normal physis.

Treatment

  • When asymptomatic, these lesions are treated with observation only.
  • Surgery is considered when a patient experiences pain secondary to muscle irritation, mechanical trauma (contusions), or an inflamed bursa over the lesion.

Differential diagnosis: Para osteal osteosarcoma, heterotopic ossification

Other features

Malignant transformation (<1% of cases) to a "secondary chondrosarcoma".

Reference: Miller's review of Orthopaedics 8th edition page number. 1881

questions.text: Muscle being tested in card test for ulnar nerve examination :
questions.solution:
Interossei Muscles and Their Functions

  • Palmar Interossei (PAD): Responsible for adduction of the fingers at the metacarpophalangeal joints.(Option C)
  • Dorsal Interossei (DAB): Responsible for abduction of the fingers at the metacarpophalangeal joints.(Option A)

Testing Interossei Muscles:

  1. Egawa's Test:
    • Purpose: Tests the dorsal interossei (abductors) of the middle finger.
    • Procedure: With the hand flat on a table, palm down, the patient is asked to move the middle finger sideways.
  2. Card Test:
    • Purpose: Tests the palmar interossei (adductors) of the fingers.
    • Procedure: A card is inserted between two extended fingers, and the patient is asked to hold it tightly while the examiner tries to pull the card out. Weak palmar interossei will make it easy to pull out the card.
    • First Dorsal Interosseous Muscle: Can be tested separately by asking the patient to abduct the index finger against resistance.

Tests for Ulnar nerve:

Card test: palmar interossei

Igawa test: dorsal interossei

Book test/Froment's sign: adductor pollicis(Option D)

Tests for Median nerve:

Pen test: Abductor pollicis brevis

Pointing index/Oschner's clasp test

Reference. J. Maheshwari's 5th Edition of Essential Orthopaedics page number: 66, 67.

questions.text: Which of the following best describes a Felon?
questions.solution:
Terminal Pulp Space Infection (Whitlow or Felon)

Surgical Anatomy:

  • The terminal pulp space is located in the volar aspect of the distal digit.
    • It is filled with compact fat, loosely partitioned by multiple fibrous septae (Fig-24.3).
  • At the proximal end, this space is closed by a deep fascia septum that connects the distal flexor crease of the finger to the periosteum, just distal to the insertion of the profundus flexor tendon.
  • Digital arteries: Before entering the space, the digital artery gives off a branch to the epiphysis at the base of the distal phalanx. Inside the space, it divides into terminal branches.

Clinical Features:

  • Second most common infection of the hand, often following a pin-prick injury.
  • Most commonly affects the index finger and thumb.
  • Key signs include:
  • Swollen, tense, and tender pulp.
  • Severe throbbing pain and excruciating tenderness, indicating possible suppuration.

Treatment:

  • Early stage: Conservative treatment may stop the infection from progressing.
  • Later stage (Suppuration): Drainage becomes necessary. This can be done by:
    • Direct incision over the center of the abscess.
    • Lateral incision just in front of the plane of the terminal phalanx.

Complications:

  1. Osteomyelitis of the terminal phalanx, often accompanied by necrosis and sequestration of the distal half.
    • Cause: Thrombo-arteritis of the terminal branches of the digital vessels.
    • The basal plate of the epiphysis is rarely affected.
  2. Pyogenic arthritis of the distal interphalangeal joint.
  3. Suppurative tenosynovitis: Rare spread of infection to the flexor tendon sheath.

Reference: J. Maheshwari's 5th Edition of Essential Orthopaedics page number. 206.

questions.text: A 28 yr old mechanic was having neuralgic pain in left forearm along the dorsal aspect. Xray was normal. Nerve conduction study showed compressive neuropathy of PIN in the forearm. Which structure can never be responsible for this condition ?
questions.solution:
Condition described in the question is PIN compression syndrome. This is an entrapment neuropathy of PIN(Posterior Interosseous nerve). The structures causing the compression are - MNEMONIC ----- FLEAS

F- Fibrous band at radial head - Option C

L- Leash of Henry (radial recurrent arterial fan) - Option B

E- ECRB edge - Option D

A- Arcade of Frohse

S- Supinator muscle edge

Unusual Causes:

  • Chronic radial head dislocation
  • Monteggia fracture-dislocation
  • Radiocapitellar rheumatoid synovitis
  • Space-occupying elbow mass (e.g., lipoma)

Differential Diagnosis:

  • PIN palsy is differentiated from extensor tendon rupture by a normal wrist tenodesis test result.

Treatment:

  • Nonoperative Treatment:
    • Activity modification
    • Splinting
    • NSAIDs (Non-Steroidal Anti-Inflammatory Drugs)
  • Surgical Treatment:
    • If no recovery is observed by 3 months, surgical decompression of the anatomic sites of compression is recommended.
    • Surgical decompression provides good to excellent results for 85% of patients.

Option A - Osborne ligament is responsible for ulnar nerve entrapment neuropathy called cubital tunnel syndrome.

Reference: Campbell's Operative Orthopaedics 14th edition page number:3878

questions.text: Match the following salient features with corresponding bone tumours:
questions.solution:
Salient Features of Specific Bone Tumors

Ewing's Sarcoma:

  • Radiographic Appearance:
    • Onion peel appearance on X-ray.
    • Most radio-sensitive bone tumor.
  • Characteristics:
    • Highly radiosensitive; tumor melts quickly but has a high recurrence rate.
    • Distant metastasis has often occurred by the time of diagnosis.
  • Treatment:
    • Local tumor control with radiotherapy (6000 rads).
    • Metastasis control with chemotherapy.

Fig. Onion peel appearance of Ewing's sarcoma

Osteoclastoma (Giant Cell Tumor - GCT):

  • Radiographic Appearance:
    • Soap bubble appearance on X-ray.
  • Mnemonic: "Rule of E":
    • Epiphyseal
    • Eccentrically placed
    • Expansile
    • Egg shell cracking
    • Excision (surgical)

Fig. Soap bubble appearance of Giant cell tumour

Osteosarcoma:

  • Radiological Features:
    1. Irregular destruction in the metaphysis, often overshadowed by new bone formation.
    2. Cortex erosion overlying the lesion.
    3. Periosteal Reaction:
      • Intense and irregular periosteal reaction as the tumor lifts the periosteum, unlike the smooth, layered reaction seen in osteomyelitis.
    4. Codman's Triangle:
      • A triangular area of new subperiosteal bone formation at the tumor-host junction.
    5. Sun Ray Appearance:
      • Tumor invades soft tissues; new bone forms along blood vessels, creating a sun-ray appearance on X-ray.

Fig. Periosteal reaction of Osteosarcoma

Unicameral Bone Cyst (UBC):

  • Radiographic Appearance:
    • Fallen leaf sign on X-ray.

Fig. Fallen leaf sign of Unicameral bone cyst



Reference: J. Maheshwari's 5th Edition of Essential Orthopaedics page number:238, 240,243, 251.

questions.text: A construction worker sustained sharp lacerated wound over inner side of wrist which he got sutured from a local quack. Gradually he started developing clawing of hand. EMG-NCV showed complete discontinuity and absent waves in ulnar nerve distribution from Guyon's canal onwards. Choose the correct statement:
questions.solution:
Claw Hand (Main-en-griffe)

Definition:

  • Claw hand refers to a deformity characterized by:
    • Hyperextension at the metacarpo-phalangeal (MP) joints.
    • Flexion at the proximal and distal interphalangeal (PIP and DIP) joints (Fig. 10.4).

Cause:

  • Occurs due to paralysis of the lumbricals, which normally:
    • Flex the MP joints.
    • Extend the PIP and DIP joints.

Paradox in Ulnar Nerve Palsy:

  • Clawing is more pronounced in low ulnar nerve palsy than in high ulnar nerve palsy.
    • In high ulnar nerve palsy, the flexors of the fingers (both the flexor digitorum profundus and flexor digitorum superficialis), which contribute to clawing, are also paralyzed. This reduces the severity of clawing.
    • In low ulnar nerve palsy, only the intrinsic muscles of hand are paralysed but 4th and 5th FDP and PDS are spared hence resulting in severe deformity.

Finger Involvement:

  • In ulnar nerve palsy, only the medial two fingers (ring and little fingers) develop clawing.
  • In combined median and ulnar nerve palsies, all four fingers exhibit clawing.

Reference: J. Maheshwari's 5th Edition of Essential Orthopaedics page number. 64.

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl presents with pain and swelling in her right thigh. After conducting a biopsy, she is diagnosed with Ewing's sarcoma of the femur. Which of the following statements about the pathology of Ewing's sarcoma is false?
questions.solution:
Ewing's Sarcoma

Overview: (Option C)

  • A highly malignant tumor typically occurring between the ages of 10 to 20 years, though it can sometimes affect individuals up to 30 years.
  • Commonly seen in the diaphysis of long bones, particularly the femur and tibia.

Pathogenesis:

  • Believed to be of neuro-ectodermal origin, associated with a t(11:22) chromosomal translocation.

Gross Appearance:

  • Tumor tissue is grey-white, soft, and may be thin, resembling pus in some cases.

Histopathology:

  • Composed of sheets of small, uniform cells that resemble lymphocytes.
  • Often, the tumor cells form pseudo-rosettes, where the cells surround a central clear area. (Option A)

Radiological Features:

  • X-rays show an onion peel appearance, which is characteristic of the layered (Option B) periosteal reaction seen in Ewing's sarcoma.

Differential Diagnosis:

  • Osteosarcoma
  • Chronic osteomyelitis

Treatment: (Option D)

  • Ewing's sarcoma is highly radiosensitive.
  • The mainstay of treatment includes:
  • Radiotherapy
  • Chemotherapy
  • Surgery (salvage surgery in some cases)

Prognosis:

  • Poor prognosis with high chances of metastasis, particularly to other bones and the lungs.

Reference: J. Maheshwari's 5th Edition of Essential Orthopaedics page number. 243

questions.text: A 4-year-old child is brought to the clinic by their parents due to instability while walking. The parents report a history of an infection in the child's right hip that was treated with intravenous antibiotics a few years ago. On physical examination, the telescopy test is positive. An X-ray reveals a well-formed acetabulum but an absence of the femoral head epiphysis. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Tom-Smith's Arthritis (Sequela of Septic Arthritis of the Hip in Infants)

  • Overview: This condition is a result of septic arthritis of the hip occurring in infants. During this stage of development, the femoral head is primarily cartilaginous and is rapidly and completely destroyed by the pyogenic infection.
  • Clinical Presentation:
    • The onset is acute, with rapid abscess formation. The abscess may either burst spontaneously or be surgically incised and heals quickly.
    • Often, it is mistaken for a superficial infection, and the child later presents with a limp but without pain.
    • On examination, the child has an unstable gait, with the affected leg being shorter.
    • Hip movements are increased in all directions, and the telescopy test is positive.
  • Radiological Findings:
    • X-ray reveals a complete absence of the femoral head and neck.
    • The acetabulum remains normally developed and round, distinguishing this condition from others.

Differential Diagnosis:

  1. Congenital Dislocation of the Hip (CDH): Option A
    • Resemblance to Tom-Smith's Arthritis: CDH can present similarly, especially when the child is of a similar age.
    • Key Differentiating Feature: In CDH, the acetabulum is shallow, whereas in Tom-Smith's arthritis, the acetabulum is normally developed despite the absence of the femoral head and neck.
  2. Slipped Capital Femoral Epiphysis (SCFE): Option C
    • Key Differentiating Feature: There is no history of infection in SCFE.
    • Age Group: SCFE commonly affects children aged 11-15 years.
  3. Transient Synovitis: Option D
    • Key Differentiating Feature: Transient synovitis presents with milder symptoms and less severe infection compared to Tom-Smith's arthritis.
    • Radiological Findings: There are no bony changes associated with transient synovitis.

Reference: J. Maheshwari's 5th Edition of Essential Orthopaedics page number. 178

questions.text: A 19 year girl presents with complain of pain over right thigh with mild swelling. No history of trauma or any infection. Pain is worst at night. MRI confirms osteoid osteoma. Choose false statement from below?
questions.solution:
Osteoid Osteoma

  • Overview: The most common true benign tumor of the bone. (Option A)
  • Pathology: Characterized by a nidus consisting of tangled arrays of partially mineralized osteoid trabeculae, surrounded by dense sclerotic bone.
  • Demographics: Typically occurs in individuals aged 5-25 years, with the tibial diaphysis being the most common site.
  • Symptoms:
    • Persistent, nagging pain that worsens at night.
    • Pain relief is commonly achieved with salicylates (e.g., aspirin). (Option B)
    • Minimal clinical signs; may present with mild tenderness at the lesion site.
    • In cases of superficial lesions, a palpable swelling might be observed.
  • Imaging (X-ray):
    • Shows a zone of sclerosis surrounding a radiolucent nidus.
    • The nidus is usually less than 1 cm in size.
  • Treatment:
    • Complete excision of the nidus along with the surrounding sclerotic bone. (Option D)
    • Bone grafting may be required in some cases.
  • Prognosis: It is not a pre-malignant condition, and the prognosis is generally excellent. (Option C)

Reference: J. Maheshwari's 5th Edition of Essential Orthopaedics page number: 235

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents with pain and swelling around the right lower thigh. On examination, the thigh is warm, tender, firm, and swelling is non-homogenous. X-ray reveals a calcified lesion extending up to the distal end of the femur. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Osteosarcoma

  • Overview: Osteosarcoma is the most common primary malignant bone tumor, primarily affecting males under 20 years of age.
  • Location: The tumor typically arises in the metaphysis of long bones, such as the femur, and may extend to the epiphyseal region.
  • Imaging Features:
    • X-rays often reveal a characteristic "sunburst" pattern, along with a Codman triangle and periosteal reaction.
  • Histology: Anaplastic mesenchymal parenchyma with tumour cells surrounded by osteoid.
  • Treatment:
    • Management includes chemotherapy followed by wide local excision of the tumor.
    • Limb salvage and reconstruction are now common, using advanced implants like mega-prosthesis, which help restore better functionality.
  • Option A (Osteochondroma) is incorrect because osteochondromas are benign and more commonly diagnosed in late adolescence or early adulthood.
  • Option C (Enchondroma) is incorrect because enchondromas are benign cartilaginous tumors found in the intramedullary bone, typically in the distal extremities of hand and feet, not the knee.
  • Option D (Chondrosarcoma/Chondroblastoma) is incorrect because chondrosarcomas typically occur in older men (30-60 years) and often affect the pelvis, spine, and other areas, not predominantly the knee in younger individuals.

Reference: J. Maheshwari's 5th Edition of Essential Orthopaedics page number: 236

questions.text: 33-year-old female presents with gradually progressive swelling of the left wrist. X-rays show erosion of bony cortex and lytic lesions at distal end of radius. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Giant Cell Tumor (GCT) / Osteoclastoma

  • Age Group: Commonly affects individuals aged 20-40 years, typically after epiphyseal fusion.
  • Common Sites:
    • Bones around the knee: lower end of the femur and upper end of the tibia.
    • The lower end of the radius is also frequently involved.
    • The tumor is usually located at the epiphysis.
  • Radiographic Features:
    • Lytic lesion: May be solitary and sometimes loculated.
    • Eccentric location, often subchondral.
    • Expansile lesion: Expansion of the overlying cortex is commonly observed.
    • Soap-bubble appearance: A homogeneous lytic lesion with trabeculae remnants, giving a loculated appearance.
    • No calcification: The tumor typically lacks calcification.
    • Minimal or no reactive sclerosis around the tumor.
    • The cortex may be thinned or perforated in certain areas.
  • Tumor Behavior:
    • The tumor generally does not invade adjacent joints.
  • Treatment:
    • Excision +/- reconstruction
    • Curratege +/- supplementary procedures like cryotherapy
    • Amputation
    • Arthrodesis/ arthroplasty
    • Radiotherapy for vertebral lesions

Reference: J. Maheshwari's 5th Edition of Essential Orthopaedics page number: 237

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with a history of persistent pain, intermittent fever, and a foul-smelling discharge and swelling in his right foot. He underwent surgery for an open fracture of the fifth metatarsal three months ago. The affected area is warm, tender, and exhibits erythema. Laboratory tests reveal an elevated white blood cell count, and a plain radiograph shows irregular bone margins. What is the most likely diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
Examination Findings in Chronic Osteomyelitis

Clinical Features:

  • Chronic Discharging Sinus:
    • A characteristic feature of chronic infection.
    • A sinus fixed to the underlying bone suggests infection originating from the bone.
    • May exhibit sprouting granulation tissue at the opening, indicating a sequestrum within the bone.
    • Sequestrum may be visible at the mouth of the sinus.
    • Surrounding healed puckered scars may indicate previous healed sinuses.
  • Thickened, Irregular Bone:
    • Noticeable when comparing the girth of the affected bone with the normal side.
  • Tenderness on Deep Palpation:
    • Usually mild and present in some cases.
  • Joint Stiffness:
    • May occur due to excessive scarring in the soft tissues around the joint or associated arthritis.

Investigations

Radiological Features:

  • Thickening and Irregularity of the Cortices:
    • Changes in the bone cortex structure.
  • Patchy Sclerosis:
    • Areas of increased bone density.
  • Bone Cavity:
    • Appears as a rarefied area surrounded by sclerosis.
  • Sequestrum:
    • Appears denser than surrounding normal bone due to lack of decalcification in dead bone.
    • Granulation tissue surrounding the sequestrum creates a radiolucent zone.
    • Sequestrum may be visible in soft tissues.
  • Involucrum and Cloacae:
    • May also be visible on radiological examination.

Fig. Radiographic features of chronic osteomyelitis

  • Option A) Acute osteomyelitis typically presents with more sudden onset and is often associated with a systemic illness.
  • Option C) Osteosarcoma would likely present with a different clinical picture, including a more aggressive course and possibly more significant systemic symptoms.
  • Option D) Diabetic foot ulcer could cause a similar presentation but would be more likely in a diabetic patient and would not typically show the classic signs of osteomyelitis on imaging.

Reference: J. Maheshwari's 5th Edition of Essential Orthopaedics page number: 172

questions.text: Which of the following is a specific radiological finding in patients with tuberculosis of the hip?
questions.solution:
Investigations for Tuberculosis of the Hip

Radiological Examination:

  • Essential Imaging:
    • X-ray examination of the pelvis, including both hips.
    • AP (anterior-posterior) and lateral views of the affected hip are necessary.
    • Including the normal hip in the same film on the AP view allows for comparison of joint spaces.
  • Advanced Imaging:
    • MRI scan and bone scan may be useful for early diagnosis.

Radiological Signs in Established TB of the Hip:

  1. Haziness:
    • The earliest sign, indicating changes in the bones around the hip.
    • Best appreciated by comparing the affected hip with the normal hip.
  2. Lytic Lesion:
    • Presence of lytic lesions in specified regions.
  3. Reduction of Joint Space:
    • Caused by destruction of cartilage.
    • Can be uniformly or irregularly diminished; better appreciated in early stages by comparing with the opposite side.
  4. Irregular Outline:
    • The outline of the articular ends of the bone becomes irregular due to the disease process.
    • In severe cases, significant portions of the femoral head or acetabulum may be destroyed.
  5. Acetabular Changes:
    • The femoral head may lie outside the acetabulum, creating a 'pseudo' acetabulum on the ilium (wandering acetabulum).
    • In some cases, the acetabulum enlarges and deepens, with the deformed head shifted medially, resembling a 'pestle and mortar'.
  6. Signs of Healing:
    • If the disease begins to heal, there may be sclerosis around the hip.
  • Option A) Joint space narrowing is more commonly associated with osteoarthritis.
  • Option B) Erosion of the acetabulum is a hallmark feature of tuberculosis of the hip due to the destructive nature of the infection.
  • Option C) Presence of a sequestrum is typically seen in osteomyelitis rather than directly in joint infections like tuberculosis.

Reference: J. Maheshwari's 5th Edition of Essential Orthopaedics page number: 197.
